Commutative Law
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Order of an element
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.
Units of a Ring
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
Ring Monomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
Euclidean function
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
Localization of a Ring

Given a ring $R$ and a multiplicative system $S \subset R$, the localization $S^{-1}R$ (or $R_S$) is the ring of fractions $ rac{a}{s}$ where $a \in R$ and $s \in S$, under an equivalence relation defined by $ rac{a}{s} =  rac{a'}{s'}$ if there exists some $s'' \in S$ such that $as's'' = a'ss''$.
Minimal Polynomial

The minimal polynomial of an element \\(\alpha\\) in a field extension is the monic polynomial of lowest degree in the base field that has \\(\alpha\\) as a root. It is a prime polynomial and generates the kernel of the evaluation homomorphism from the polynomial ring of the base field to the field generated by \\(\alpha\\). 
(Alt.2)
Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension and $\alpha \in L$ an element that is algebraic over $K$. The unique monic polynomial $f \in K[X]$ of smallest degree such that $f(\alpha)=0$ is called the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ over $K$.
Finitely Generated Field Extension
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called finitely generated if there exist finitely many elements $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n})$.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Splitting Field of Polynomial
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.
Normalizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
Kernel of Map
The kernel of \( f \) is defined as:\[\mathrm{Ker}(f) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) = 0 \} and is hence a subset of the Domain A.\]
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of the order of an element in a group relies on the concept of a group and the cyclic group generated by an element in that group.
The definition of units of a ring relies on the concept of a ring and the multiplicative inverse within that ring.
The definition of a ring monomorphism relies on the concept of a ring and a ring homomorphism.
The definition of a Euclidean function relies on the concept of a Euclidean domain, which is a type of ring.
The definition of the localization of a ring relies on the concept of a ring and a multiplicative system within that ring.
The definition of a minimal polynomial relies on the concept of a field extension and the polynomial ring of the base field.
The definition of a finitely generated field extension relies on the concept of a field extension.
The definition of the multiplicative group of a finite field relies on the concept of a finite field and its nonzero elements forming a group.
The definition of a splitting field of a polynomial relies on the concept of a field extension and the polynomial ring of the base field.
The definition of the normalizer of a subset in a group relies on the concept of a group and its subset.
The definition of the kernel of a map relies on the concept of a map (or function) and its domain.
